{{about|the 2016 cycling season and results|other sports' results|2016 in sports}} {{Year box}} {{Year nav topic5|2016|cycling}}
The '''2016 in cycling''' results is given as follows:
==[[BMX racing]]== * January 1 – December 11: 2016 UCI BMX Events Calendar<ref>[http://www.uci.ch/bmx/calendar/#date=20161012&view=list&categ=0&country=0&classc=0 2016 UCI BMX Events Calendar]</ref>

{{Infobox International Ice Hockey Competition | tourney_name = | year = 2021 | other_titles = | image = | size = | caption = | country = Belarus | country2 = Latvia | dates = 7–23 May 2021 | num_teams = | venues = 2 | cities = 2 | winners = | count = | games = | goals = | attendance = | scoring_leader = | mvp = | updated = | prevseason = [[2020 IIHF World Championship|2020]] | nextseason = [[2022 IIHF World Championship|2022]] }} The '''2021 IIHF World Championship''' will be co-hosted by [[Minsk]], [[Belarus]] and [[Riga]], [[Latvia]], as the [[IIHF]] announced on 19 May 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.iihfworlds2017.com/en/news/to-minsk-riga-in-2021/|title=To Minsk & Riga in 2021!|last=Merk|first=Martin|date=2017-05-19|publisher=IIHF.com|accessdate=2017-05-20}} Their joint bid won by a very tight margin against the Finnish bid with the cities of [[Tampere]] and [[Helsinki]]. Each city will host one group and two quarter-final games, with both semi-finals and the medal games to be played in Minsk. It will be the second time hosting for both cities; Minsk was the sole host of the [[2014 IIHF World Championship]], while Riga hosted the [[2006 IIHF World Championship]]. ==Venues== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- |'''[[Minsk]]''' |'''[[Riga]]''' |- | [[Minsk Arena]]
Capacity: 15,100 | [[Arena Riga]]
Capacity: 10,300 |- | [[File:Minsk Arena.JPG|180px]] | |} ==Participants== *{{ih|BLR}}† *{{ih|LAT}}† :
''† = Qualified as host.''
==External links== *[https://www.facebook.com/minskriga2021 Minsk-Riga 2021 on Facebook] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Ice Hockey World Championships}} [[Category:IIHF World Championship|2021 Men]] [[Category:2021 IIHF Men's World Ice Hockey Championships|IIHF World Championship]] [[Category:International ice hockey competitions hosted by Belarus|2021 IIHF World Championship]] [[Category:International ice hockey competitions hosted by Latvia|2021 IIHF World Championship]] [[Category:2021 in ice hockey]] [[Category:2021 in Belarusian sport]] [[Category:2021 in Latvian sport]] [[Category:Sports competitions in Minsk|2021 IIHF World Championship]] [[Category:Sports competitions in Riga|2021 IIHF World Championship]] [[Category:Scheduled sports events|IIHF World Championship]] [[Category:May 2021 sports events]] [[Category:Ice hockey in Riga]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Arena Nürnberger Versicherung | nickname = | former_names = Nuremberg Arena {{small|(2001-05)}} | fullname = | image = Ледяная арена.jpg | caption = | image_size = 250px | location = [[Nuremberg]], [[Bavaria]], [[Germany]] | opened = 15 February 2001 | renovated = | owner = | tenants = [[Nürnberg Ice Tigers]] (2001–present)
[[Brose Bamberg]] (2015–present) (selected matches) | architect = | seating_capacity = [[Rock concert]]s:
11,000
[[Concert|Classical concerts]]:
7,500
[[Boxing]]: 9,400
[[Handball]]: 8,200
[[Basketball]]: 8,200
[[Tennis]]: 8,200
[[Ice Hockey]]: 7,809 }} The '''Arena Nürnberger Versicherung''' (originally known as the '''Nuremberg Arena''') is a [[Multi-purpose stadium|multi-use]] [[arena|indoor arena]] that is located in [[Nuremberg]], [[Germany]]. It can host sports matches, including those of [[tennis]], [[ice hockey]], [[handball]], and [[basketball]], as well as musical [[concerts]]. It has a capacity of up to 9,400 people for sports,[http://www.arena-nuernberg.de/besucher-service/saalplan-und-bestuhlung/ Bestuhlung {{de icon}}.] and up to 11,000 people for concerts.[http://www.arena-nuernberg.de/arena/zahlen-und-fakten/ und Fakten zur ARENA {{de icon}}.] ==History== The arena opened in 2001. On 22 April 2003, Irish vocal pop band [[Westlife]] held a concert for their [[Unbreakable Tour (Westlife concert tour)|Unbreakable Tour]] supporting their album [[Unbreakable - The Greatest Hits Vol. 1]]. In 2005, it was renamed '''Arena Nürnberger Versicherung''' to reflect its sponsorship by a local insurance firm. On 7 November 2009, [[David Haye]] won the [[World Boxing Association|WBA]] [[List of WBA world champions#Heavyweight (Super belt: Muhammad Ali)|Heavyweight Championship]], against [[Nikolai Valuev]], at the arena, in his first attempt at the heavyweight title. The arena is the home venue for the [[Deutsche Eishockey Liga|German Ice Hockey League]] club, [[Nürnberg Ice Tigers|Thomas Sabo Ice Tigers Nürnberg]], and was also the home arena for the now defunct [[Basketball Bundesliga|German League]] basketball club, [[Falke Nürnberg]]. The [[Basketball Bundesliga|German Basketball League]] club, [[Brose Bamberg]], has also played [[EuroLeague]] home games at the arena in the [[2005–06 Euroleague|2005–06 EuroLeague season]], against the [[Greek Basket League|Greek League]] club [[AEK Athens BC|AEK Athens]],[http://www.euroleague.net/main/results/showgame?gamecode=74&seasoncode=E2005 GHP BAMBERG 71 AEK ATHENS 61 DECEMBER 15, 2005 ARENA NÜRNBERGER VERSICHERUNGEN.][http://www.arena-nuernberg.de/arena/nutzungsvarianten/ansichten-sport/ Bilder von Sportvarianten Basketball {{de icon}}.] during the [[2015–16 Euroleague|2015–16 EuroLeague season]] against the [[Liga ACB|Spanish League]] club [[Real Madrid Baloncesto|Real Madrid]],[http://www.euroleague.net/main/results/showgame?gamecode=181&seasoncode=E2015 ROSE BASKETS BAMBERG 86 REAL MADRID 90 FEBRUARY 25, 2016 ARENA NURNBERGER VERSICHERUNG.] and during the [[2016–17 Euroleague|2016–17 EuroLeague season]] against the [[Turkish Basketball Super League|Turkish Super League]] club [[Efes S.K.|Efes]].[http://www.euroleague.net/main/results/showgame?gamecode=89&seasoncode=E2016 2016-17 Regular Season Round 12 DECEMBER 15, 2016 ARENA NURNBERGER VERSICHERUNG.] They also played a home game in the [[2017–18 EuroLeague|2017–18 season]], against [[FC Barcelona Basket|FC Barcelona]].[http://www.euroleague.net/main/results/showgame?gamecode=53&seasoncode=E2017 NOVEMBER 15, 2017 CET: 20:00 LOCAL TIME: 20:00 ARENA NURNBERGER VERSICHERUNG.] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.arena-nuernberg.de/ Official Site] {{de icon}} {{IIHF World In [[chess]], '''artificial castling''' (also called '''castling by hand''') refers to a maneuver in which a [[king (chess)|king]] which has lost the right to [[castling|castle]] achieves a castled position in several normal moves, instead of the one special move. {{algebraic notation|pos=tocleft}} ==Examples== {| style="float:right;" border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" |- valign="top" | {{Chess diagram | tright | |rd| |bd|qd|kd|bd| |rd |pd|pd|pd|pd| |bl|pd|pd | | |nd| | | | | | | | | |pd| | | | | | | |nd| | | | | |nl| | |nl| | |pl|pl|pl|pl| |pl|pl|pl |rl| |bl|ql|kl| | |rl | Position after 5.Bxf7+?! }} | {{Chess diagram | tright | |rd| |bd|qd| |rd|kd| |pd|pd|pd|pd|bd| |pd|pd | | |nd| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |nl|nl| | | | | | | | | | | |pl|pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl |rl| |bl|ql| |rl|kl| | Position after 9...Kg8 }} |} After the following common sequence of moves: :'''1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nf6 4. Nc3 Nxe4 5. Bxf7+?!''' (first diagram) White sees that if he recaptures with 5.Nxe4, Black responds with 5...d5, forking knight and bishop and winning back the piece. In that case, Black has not won material, but has destroyed White's center. Instead of allowing d5, White hopes to cause trouble for Black by returning the piece while depriving him of the right to castle. However, Black can easily castle artificially, for example: :'''5... Kxf7 6. Nxe4 Be7 7. 0-0''' White castles "naturally". :'''7... Rf8''' Black begins castling artificially. :'''8. d4 exd4 9. Nxd4 Kg8''' (second diagram) Black has achieved a normal castled position (Rf8, Kg8), but in several moves. The absence of any pawns in the center indicates that king safety is of particular importance in this position. Black's development lags slightly, but he also possesses the bishop pair and a [[queenside]] [[pawn (chess)|pawn]] majority, so his position is at least equal. {{clear}} {| style="float:left;" border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" |- valign="top" | {{Chess diagram small | tleft | |rd|nd| |qd|kd|bd| |rd | | | | |pd|pd|pd|pd | | | |pd| |nd| | | | |pd|pl| | | | | | | | |pl| | | | | |nl| | | | | |pl|pl| | | |pl|pl|pl |rl| |bl|ql| |kl|nl|rl | After 8.Kxf1 in the [[Benko Gambit]] }} | {{Chess diagram small | tleft | |rd| | |qd| |rd|kd| | | | |nd|pd|pd|bd|pd | | | |pd| |nd|pd| | | |pd|pl| | | | | | | | |pl| | | | | |nl| | |nl|pl| |pl|pl| | | |pl|kl|pl |rl| |bl|ql| | | |rl | Position after 11.Nf3 Nbd7 }} |}
In an even more common [[Chess opening|opening]] (a main line of the [[Benko Gambit]], ''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings|ECO]]'' A59), White uses the g2-square in an artificial castle maneuver to safeguard his king after an exchange of bishops on f1 precludes castling normally: :'''1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 c5 3. d5 b5 4. cxb5 a6 5. bxa6 Bxa6 6. Nc3 d6 7. e4 Bxf1 8. Kxf1''' (first diagram) '''8... g6 9. g3 Bg7 10. Kg2 0-0 11. Nf3 Nbd7''' (second diagram). White has completed the artificial castle maneuver of his king and is ready to continue with 12.Re1 (or other moves). {{clear}} ==Praxis== {{Chess diagram | tright | Mestel vs. Makarichev, 1979 | | | |rd| | | |rd |pd|pd|pd| | |pd|pd|kd | | |bd| | |qd| |pd | | |ql| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |pl| |bl| | | |pl|pl|pl| |rl| |pl|pl |rl| | | | | |kl| | Position after 17...Kh7 }} The following game between [[Jonathan Mestel]] and [[Sergey Makarichev]] played in [[Hastings International Chess Congress|Hastings]] 1979 features yet another way to artificially castle: :'''1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. Bc4 Nxe4 4. Nc3 Nc6 5. 0-0 Nxc3 6. dxc3 h6 7. Qd5 Qf6 8. Re1 Bd6 9. Nxe5 Bxe5 10. f4 d6 11. fxe5 dxe5 12. Bb5 Bd7 13. Bxc6 Bxc6 14. Rxe5+ Kf8 15. Qc5+ Kg8 16. Re2 Rd8 17. Be3 Kh7''' (see diagram) The king has finally reached a safe haven and now Black takes over the initiative. '''18. Qxa7? Rhe8 19. Rf2 Qg6 20. h3 Re4! 21. Bd4 Rd5! 22. Rd1 Rg5 23. Kf1 Re6 24. g4 Bb5+ 25. Kg1 Rxg4+! 26. Kh2 Rg3 27. Rdd2 Rxh3+! 28. Kxh3 Qh5+ {{nowrap|0–1}}''' {{Chess diagram | tleft | Heidenfeld vs. Hecht, 1974 |rd| |bd| |kd| | |rd |pd|pd| | | |pd|pd|pd | | |nd| |pd| | | |qd| | |pd|pl| | | | | |pd|pl| |pl| | |bd| |pl| | |nl| | |pl| |pl| |bl| |pl|pl |rl| |bl|ql|kl| | |rl | Position after 12...Qa5 }} A unique and even humorous artificial castling took place in the game Heidenfeld–Hecht, played in the [[Nice]] [[Chess Olympiad]] 1974: :'''1. e4 Nf6 2. Nc3 d5 3. e5 Ne4 4. d4 Nxc3 5. bxc3 e6 6. Bd3 c5 7. f4 Nc6 8. Nf3 Qa5 9. Bd2 Qa4! 10. Be3 c4 11. Be2 Ba3 12. Bc1? Qa5''' (see diagram) White's queenside pawns were under heavy pressure, and "usual" moves such as 13.Bd2? Bb2, 13.Bxa3 Qxc3+! or 13.Qd2 Bxc1 would have all led to a loss of a pawn. So, White came up with the following unusual maneuver: '''13. Kd2! Be7 14. Qe1 Bd7 15. Ke3''' Now that the queen guards c3, the king can continue his journey to safety. '''15... f6 16. Rf1 fxe5 17. fxe5 0-0 18. Kf2 Be8! 19. Kg1''' White has "castled" in five moves instead of the usual one, but maintained material equality (although after '''19... Bg6''', Black was still better, and eventually won). {{clear left}} == See also == * [[Castling]] * [[Chess]] == References == {{Unreferenced|date=August 2007}} {{chess}} [[Category:Chess terminology]] [[Category:Chess strategy]]

{{coord|28.228256|-81.641313|display=title}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Baseball City Stadium | nickname = | image = | fullname = | location = 300 Stadium Way
[[Davenport, Florida]] 33837 | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = 1987 | opened = February 7, 1988 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = 2005 | owner = [[Harcourt Trade Publishers|Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Park Group]] (1988-1989)
[[Anheuser-Busch|Busch Entertainment Corporation]] (1989-1990) | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = $13,000,000 | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = {{plain list| *[[Kansas City Royals]] ([[Major League Baseball|MLB]]; spring training [[1987 Kansas City Royals season|1987]]—[[2002 Kansas City Royals season|2002]]) *[[Baseball City Royals]] ([[Florida State League|FSL]]; 1988-1992) *[[Arizona League Royals|Gulf Coast League Royals]] ([[Gulf Coast League|GCL]]; 2001-2002) }} | seating_capacity = 8,000 | dimensions = Left - 330 ft.
Center - 410 ft.
Right - 330 ft. }} '''Baseball City Stadium''' was a [[stadium]] located in [[Davenport, Florida]] (near Haines City) that was in use from 1988-2002. It was a portion of the [[Boardwalk and Baseball]] theme park. The two facilities adjoined at the intersection of Interstate 4 and Route 27, about 25 miles southwest of [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]]. The facility had five practice fields in addition to the stadium. It was primarily used for [[baseball]] and was the [[spring training]] home of [[Kansas City Royals]] prior to the team moving to [[Surprise Stadium]] in 2003. The ballpark had a capacity of 8,000 people. ==History== The stadium opened on February 7, 1988; it was designed to be the cornerstone of the Boardwalk and Baseball theme park. The Royals were quick to jump at the opportunity to play in a brand new stadium and signed on for a 15-year contract. The stadium's first event was the 1988 Pizza Hut All-Star Softball game, played in front of 4,700 fans.{{cite news |title=Boggs helps AL beat NL in softball |author=Durward Buck |newspaper=The Ledger|date=1988-02-08 |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=C7USAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9vsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2826,3968895&dq=baseball-city-stadium&hl=en|page=1D, 5D}} The Royals played their first spring training game at the ballpark on March 4, 1988, in front of 3,281 who saw them lose 9-7 to the [[Houston Astros]].{{cite news |title=Baseball by the Boardwalk |author=Muuray Chass|newspaper=New York Times|date=1988-03-05 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/05/sports/baseball-by-the-boardwalk.html|page=49}} The Royals also moved their Single A [[Florida State League]] affiliate, renamed The [[Baseball City Royals]] into the park for the 1988 season. However, the Boardwalk and Baseball theme park was very rapidly becoming a financial disaster. The owners and developers of the park, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich (now Harcourt, a division of [[Reed Elsevier]]), put very little money into the park, and almost all money went into the Baseball Stadium. The property was originally a failed park called [[Circus World (theme park)|Circus World]], and HBJ simply renovated and re-opened the park, without adding new rides, hoping that the renaming along with the stadium would allow it to compete with nearby [[Walt Disney World]]. Quickly the park started to cut costs, including closing at dusk and laying off several employees. In September 1989 HBJ sold the theme park and stadium to [[Anheuser-Busch]]. In 1990 Anheuser-Busch closed the theme park, and by 1993 almost the entire park had been torn down. Following the 1992 season the Baseball City Royals pulled out of the Florida State League and moved to [[Wilmington, Delaware]]. Kansas City would continue to use the Stadium as it was a very modern spring training facility and still drew very solid attendance numbers. Anheuser-Busch kept the stadium open rather than break their contract that they had with the Royals. In 2001 the Royals would also move their Rookie League team, the [[Arizona League Royals|Gulf Coast League Royals]] into the stadium. However, when the contract finally ran out at the end of the 2002 season, the Royals moved all of their spring training and rookie league operations West to [[Surprise, Arizona]], where a brand new $20 million park was being built and was offered to any team willing to leave [[Florida]]. Soon after, the stadium and the [[IMAX Theater]], which were the only remaining parts of the original theme park, were demolished. ==Present day== After sitting idle for over a decade, the land was sold to developer Victor Posner in 2001. The ballpark was torn down in 2005 to make way for the new [[Posner Park]]; a retail complex with several big box stores opened on the site in 2008. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.baseballpilgrimages.com/spring/baseballcity.html Baseball Pilgrimages: Baseball City Stadium] *[http://www.digitalballparks.com/Grapefruit/Baseball.html Digital Ballparks: Baseball City Stadium] *[https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Baseball_City_Stadium BR Bullpen: Baseball City Stadium] {{Kansas City Royals}} {{FSL ballparks}} [[Category:Defunct minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Grapefruit League venues]] [[Category:Kansas City Royals spring training venues]] [[Category:1988 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1988]] [[Category:2005 disestablishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 2005]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in Florida]]

9350 [[Ribeira Brava, Madeira|Ribeira Brava]]
[[Madeira]], Portugal |built = 2007 |opened = 7 September 2007 |renovated = |closed = |demolished = |owner = [[Região Autónoma da Madeira]] |operator = Sociedade de Desenvolvimento Ponta do Oeste |surface = Grass |construction_cost = €7,7 million |architect = |former_names = |tenants = [[C.F. União|União]] (2014–present) |seating_capacity = 2600 |dimensions = 105 x 68 metres| }} '''Centro Desportivo da Madeira''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Ribeira Brava, Madeira]], Portugal. It is used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches. The stadium is able to hold 2,500 people and was built in 2007.{{cite web|title=Centro Desportivo da Madeira|url=http://www.cm-ribeirabrava.pt/index.php?lang=pt&s=directorio&pid=248&title=centro_desportivo_da_madeira_#|work=cm-ribeirabrava.pt|accessdate=30 June 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.cm-ribeirabrava.pt/index.php?lang=pt&s=directorio&pid=248&title=centro_desportivo_da_madeira_# Municipality of Ribeira Brava] * [http://www.footballzz.co.uk/estadio.php?id=4056 Centro Desportivo da Madeira at ZeroZero] {{C.F. União}} {{coord missing|Portugal}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Centro Desportivo da Madeira}} [[Category:C.F. União]] [[Category:Football venues in Portugal]] [[Category:Sport in Madeira]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Portugal]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Madeira]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2007]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Portugal]]

8,000 | dimensions = }} '''Estadio Segundo Aranda Torres''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Huacho]], [[Peru]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[Total Chalaco]] of the [[Peruvian Segunda División]] and [[Juventud Barranco]] of the [[Copa Perú]]. The stadium holds 8,000 spectators. ==External links== *[http://www.munihuacho.gob.pe/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1410:remodelacion-del-estadio-segundo-aranda-torres&catid=24:anteriores Stadium information] *[http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=451e40093c8a37c14be5d1f68d74d022&hl=es&ct=lc Stadium in 3D gallery] {{Peru-sports-venue-stub}} {{coord|11|06|04|S|77|36|16|W|type:landmark_source:kolossus-eswiki|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in Peru|Segundo Aranda Torres]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Lima Region]]

{{Infobox film | name = Five Red Tulips | image = | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Jean Stelli]] | producer = [[Raymond Borderie]] | writer = [[Charles Exbrayat]]

[[Raymond Bussières]] | music = [[René Sylviano]] | cinematography = [[Marcel Grignon]] | editing = [[Madame Lamart]] | studio = [[Compagnie Industrielle et Commerciale Cinématographique|CICC]] | distributor = Les Films Corona | released = 23 March 1949 | runtime = | country = France | language = [[French language|French]] | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Five Red Tulips''''' (French: '''''Cinq tulipes rouges''''') is a 1949 French [[crime film]] directed by [[Jean Stelli]] and starring [[René Dary]], [[Suzanne Dehelly]] and [[Raymond Bussières]].Rège p.939 The film's sets were designed by the [[art director]] [[Jacques Colombier (art director)|Jacques Colombier]]. During the [[Tour de France]], five riders are murdered. ==Cast== * [[René Dary]] as Pierre Lusanne * [[Suzanne Dehelly]] as Colonelle * [[Raymond Bussières]] as Albert 'La Puce' Jacquin * [[Pierre-Louis]] as Charolles * [[Robert Berri]] as Jacques Mauval * [[Robert Le Fort]] as Basile * [[Emilio Carrer]] as Gambarra * [[Robert Blome]] as Jef Dooksen * [[René Robert (actor)|René Robert]] * [[Luc Andrieux]] as Charles Brugeat * [[Roger Bontemps (actor)|Roger Bontemps]] as Un reporter * [[Marian (actress)|Marian]] * [[Jean-Jacques Lécot]] * [[Claude Larry]] * [[Bob d'Arcy]] * [[Jean Debray]] as Tonnelier * [[Jean Nosserot]] as Fuseau * [[Émile Genevois]] as Robert * [[Coussolle]] * [[Orgaert]] * [[Marcel Loche]] * [[René Hell]] * [[Edith Guarini]] * [[Annette Poivre]] as Annette Jacquin * [[Jean Brochard]] as L'inspecteur-chef Honoré Ricoul * [[Albert Broquin]] as Un mécano * [[Maguy Horiot]] * [[Frédéric Mariotti]] as Un inspecteur * [[Jacques Mattler]] as Le directeur de la P.J. * [[Fernand Mithouard]] as Max Everkampf * [[Marcelle Rexiane]] as La caissière * [[René Stern]] as Le maître d'hôtel == References == == Bibliography == * Rège, Philippe. ''Encyclopedia of French Film Directors, Volume 1''. Scarecrow Press, 2009. == External links == * {{IMDb title|0171182}} [[Category:1949 films]] [[Category:1940s crime films]] [[Category:1940s sports films]] [[Category:French crime films]] [[Category:French sports films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:Films set in France]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Jean Stelli]] [[Category:Cycling films]] {{1940s-France-film-stub}} [[Category:French black-and-white films]]

{{infobox country at games | NOC = GHA | NOCname = Ghana Olympic Committee | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1984 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] | competitors = 23 | sports = | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }}
'''[[Ghana]]''' competed at the '''[[1984 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]], [[United States]]. The nation returned to the Olympic Games after boycotting both the [[1976 Summer Olympics|1976]] and [[American-led boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics|1980 Games]].
==Results by event==
===[[Athletics at the 1984 Summer Olympics|Athletics]]=== '''Men's 200 metres''' *[[James Idun]] :* Heat — 22.55 (→ did not advance)
'''Men's 400 metres''' *[[Charles Moses (athlete)|Charles Moses]] :* Heat — 50.39 (→ did not advance) *Fred Owusu (→ did not compete)
'''Men's Long Jump''' * [[Francis Dodoo]] :* Qualification — did not start (→ did not advance, no ranking)
===[[Boxing at the 1984 Summer Olympics|Boxing]]=== '''Men's Light Flyweight (– 48 kg)''' * [[Michael Dankwa]] *# First Round — Lost to [[Yehuda Ben Haim]] (ISR), 1:4
'''Men's Bantamweight (– 54 kg)''' *[[Amon Neequaye]] *# First Round — Bye *# Second Round — Lost to [[Ndaba Dube]] (ZIM), 0:5
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060622162855/http://www.la84foundation.org/5va/reports_frmst.htm Official Olympic Reports]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Griffin Park | image = [[File:Griffin Park aerial 2011.jpg|250px]] | fullname = Griffin Park | nickname = | coordinates = {{coord|51|29|17.46|N|0|18|9.50|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | publictransit ={{rail-interchange|gb|Rail}} {{rws|Brentford}} | owner = [[Brentford F.C.]] | location = Braemer Road
[[Brentford]]
Middlesex
TW8 0NT | built = January–September 1904 | opened = September 1904 | seating_capacity = 12,300 | tenants = [[Brentford F.C.]] (1904–''present'')
[[London Broncos#London Broncos|London Broncos]] (2002–2006)
[[Chelsea F.C. Reserves]] (2007–2010) | dimensions = 110 x 73 yd (100 x 67 metres) }} '''Griffin Park''' is a [[association football|football]] ground in [[Brentford]], situated in the [[London Borough of Hounslow]], Greater [[London]]. It has been the home ground of [[Football League Championship|Championship]] club [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] since it was built in 1904. The ground is situated in a predominantly residential area and is known for being the only [[English league football]] ground to have a [[pub]] on each corner. The ground gets its name from the [[griffin]], featured in the logo of [[Fuller's Brewery]], which at one point owned the orchard on which the stadium was built. == History == === Planning, construction and opening === Between forming in 1889 and prior to 1904, [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] played at five grounds around [[Ealing]] – Clifden Road, Benns Field, Shotters Field, Cross Road and Boston Park Cricket Ground.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 66}} In 1903, [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] chairman [[Henry Norris (businessman)|Henry Norris]] (a prominent [[Estate Agents Ombudsman|estate agent]]), Brentford manager [[Dick Molyneux]] and club president Edwin Underwood negotiated a 21-year lease at a [[peppercorn rent]] on an [[orchard]] along the Ealing Road (owned by local [[brewery|brewers]] [[Fuller, Smith and Turner]]), with the option to buy the [[Freehold (law)|freehold]] at a later date for £5,000. After a gypsy camp was removed from the site, work began on building the ground in January 1904, under the guidance of architects Parr & Kates. The orchard was cut down by local volunteers, who were allowed to keep the wood.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} The ground was initially built with a 20,000 capacity in mind, with a provision for an increase to 30,000–40,000.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} An 800-capacity stand from Boston Park was rebuilt alongside the Braemar Road side of the ground, with an extension alongside taking the stand's capacity to 1,500.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} Beneath and behind the stand were three dressing rooms (one for each team and one for officials), a number of offices and a recreation room.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} The ground was named 'Griffin Park' after a nearby [[Public house|pub]], The Griffin, which was owned by the [[Griffin Brewery]] and was used as [[dressing room]]s and for accommodation.{{cite web |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/news-opinion/looking-back-eddie-menday-football-8110655 |title=Looking Back with Eddie Menday: Football grew out of rowing club |last=Eddie Menday |website=getwestlondon |access-date=27 November 2014}} After a number of trial games, Griffin Park was opened on 1 September 1904. Season tickets for the [[1904–05 Brentford F.C. season|1904–05]] season (priced between 10 [[shilling]]s and one [[Guinea (coin)|guinea]]) sold out.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} === The first matches === [[File:Griffin Park, London, September 2015.jpg|thumb|Griffin Park pictured from the New Road stand, September 2015.]] The first competitive match to be played at Griffin Park was a [[Western Football League|Western League]] fixture versus [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] on 1 September 1904.{{cite book|url=|title=Brentford Football Club Official Matchday Magazine versus AFC Bournemouth 04/09/04|last=|first=|publisher=Dunwoody Sports Marketing|year=2004|isbn=|location=Newbury|page=6|accessdate=}} The Braemar Road grandstand had been completed by the time of the fixture, but as the dressing rooms were not ready, the players were forced to change at the public baths in Clifden Road. The borough surveyor also declared the grandstand unsafe and banned its use until improvements had been made.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} Argyle scored the first competitive goal at the ground through [[Fred Buck]], but four minutes from the final whistle, [[Tommy Shanks]] converted a [[James Swarbrick]] cross to secure a 1–1 draw. The attendance was estimated at between 4,000 and 5,000. The first truly first team fixture to be played at the ground was a [[Southern Football League|Southern League First Division]] match on 3 September 1904, which yielded a 0–0 draw between Brentford and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. The Bees would have to wait until 22 October 1904 for their first victory at the ground, a 2–0 win over [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]]. The first [[The Football League|Football League]] match to be played at the ground was on the opening day of the [[1920–21 Brentford F.C. season|1920–21]] season, a 3–0 [[Football League Division Three|Third Division]] defeat to [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]].{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 55}} === Development === [[File:Griffin_Park,_Braemar_Road_forecourt,_January_2015.jpg|thumb|The forecourt behind the Braemar Road stand, pictured in January 2015, with the club offices and bar visible.]] A new grandstand was constructed on the Braemar Road side of the ground using £5,000 of the money generated from Brentford's run to the fifth round of the [[FA Cup]] during the [[1926–27 Brentford F.C. season|1926–27]] season,{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} replacing the 'cow shed'.{{Cite book|title=100 Years Of Brentford|publisher=Brentford FC|year=1989|isbn=0951526200|editor-last=White|editor-first=Eric|location=|page=122}} Unlike the old grandstand, the new stand ran the length of the pitch.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} After the season, it was announced that Griffin Park would be completely redeveloped over the following decade.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} Concrete terracing was installed at the Ealing Road end of the ground in 1930.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} A new stand was constructed at the Brook Road end of the ground in the 1933 off-season and the New Road terrace was extended the following year to allow a further 5,000 supporters to be accommodated.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=140, 142, 146}} A further extension to the terracing and a roof was added prior to Brentford's debut [[Football League First Division|First Division]] season in [[1935–36 Brentford F.C. season|1935–36]], taking the New Road stand's capacity to 20,000.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=140, 142, 146}} Little development occurred at Griffin Park between the mid-1930s, and the mid-1980s.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} The frontage of the Braemar Road stand was rebuilt in 1963, adding club offices and a club room.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=250}} Flats were built in a spare, matchday parking area behind the Ealing Road terrace in 1985 and the following year the Brook Road '[[Spion Kop (stadiums)|kop]]' was torn down and replaced by a two-tiered stand,{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} now colloquially known as the '[[Wendy house|Wendy House]]'.{{Cite web |url=http://www.footballgroundguide.com/leagues/england/championship/griffin-park-brentford.html |title=Griffin Park {{!}} Brentford FC {{!}} Football Ground Guide |website=www.footballgroundguide.com |access-date=23 October 2015}} On the New Road side of the ground, the 1930s extension to the terrace was removed, with a new sheet metal wall added to the back of the stand.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} The pitch was moved a few metres to the west in 2006, in order to accommodate box goal nets and the following year, a roof was finally added to the Ealing Road terrace. Numerous improvements were made after Brentford's promotion to the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] in 2014, including resurfacing of access areas, extra [[CCTV]], new signage, new heated seats in the [[Technical area|dugouts]] and [[AstroTurf]] installed in the pitch-side run-off areas.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/july/griffin-park-facelift-in-photos/ |title=A photo gallery of the Griffin Park refurbishments over the summer of 2014 |last=Chapman |first=Mark |website=brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=18 August 2015}} With the club placed in the Championship playoff places in January 2015, additional work was carried out on the New Road stand ahead of a deadline for submission of a report to the [[Premier League]], which outlined development plans ahead of a potential promotion.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislocallondon.co.uk/news/11752792._/ |title=Brentford hoping to stay at Griffin Park should Premier League beckon |website=This Is Local London |access-date=18 August 2015}} [[LED]] [[Advertising board|advertising boards]] were installed at the ground for the first time during the [[2017–18 Brentford F.C. season|2017–18]] season and [[goal-line technology]] was installed at the ground during the 2017 off-season.{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/july/led-announcement/|title=Brentford FC Brentford Football Club Invest in LED Perimeter Advertising System|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=26 July 2017|language=en-gb}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/august/goal-line-technology-first-use/|title=Brentford FC History made at Griffin Park on Saturday|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=13 August 2017|language=en-gb}} === Crowd disturbance === The only occasion on which Griffin Park has been closed due to crowd trouble was following a [[Football League Third Division South|Third Division South]] match versus [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on 12 September 1925.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 38-39}} Ill-feeling on the pitch sparked trouble on the terraces and following the [[Referee (association football)|referee]]'s report, the [[The Football Association|FA]] closed the ground for 14 days.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 38-39}} The following home match against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] was moved to [[Selhurst Park]], where Brentford suffered a 2–0 defeat and dropped to bottom place in the Football League.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 38-39}} === Wartime bombing === Griffin Park was hit by two high-explosive bombs in 1940 and 1941, during the [[Second World War]].{{cite web|author=University of Portsmouth, in collaboration with the National Archives and funded by JISC. |url=http://www.bombsight.org/bombs/16057/ |title=High Explosive Bomb at Braemar Road , London – Bomb Sight – Mapping the World War 2 London Blitz |publisher=Bomb Sight |date= |accessdate=15 August 2014}} Six matches were abandoned or postponed during [[the Blitz]].{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 137-138}} === The "Great Fire of Brentford" === [[File:Brentford vs Wycombe Wanderers, Griffin Park, December 2007.jpg|thumb|The Braemar Road stand, visible during the [[Boxing Day]] match versus [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]] in 2007.]] At 11:30 PM on 1 February 1983, a fire broke out in the Braemar Road Stand, possibly due to an electrical fault in the boiler room under the stand.{{cite web |url=http://www.newsshopper.co.uk/news/2027192.0/ |title=Nostalgia: From our picture files 25 years ago |website=News Shopper |access-date=23 October 2015}} The fire quickly spread through the timber used in the construction of the stand.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} [[Groundsman]] Alec Banks, who lived under the stand, was rescued by then-Brentford player [[Stan Bowles]] and his wife Jane.{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~2788146,00.html |title=Brentford {{!}} News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} WHERE ARE THEY NOW? |date=25 July 2012 |website=brentfordfc.co.uk |accessdate=27 March 2017}} 60 people were evacuated from homes nearby and an estimated £150,000 worth of damage was caused, including 800 seats, the away dressing room, the gymnasium, the kit store and the laundry.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} It was after the reconstruction that the players' tunnel was moved to the western corner of the Braemar Road Stand, with the players having previously emerged from a tunnel at the half way line.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=15-20}} === "Fortress Griffin Park" === Brentford set an English football record when the club won all 21 home games during the [[1929–30 Brentford F.C. season|1929–30]] Third Division South season.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 72}} Despite the record (which still stands), the Bees finished as runners-up to Plymouth Argyle and failed to win promotion to [[Football League Division Two|Second Division]].{{cite web|title = England 1929/30|url = http://www.rsssf.com/engpaul/FLA/1929-30.html|website = www.rsssf.com|accessdate = 18 August 2015}} Brentford finished the 2014 calendar year with the best home record in the Football League, winning 17 of 23 games (two more than the next-best tally) and accruing a 78% winning record.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2015/january/fortress-griffin-park-in-2014/ |title=Brentford with best home record in Football League |last=Brett |first=Ciaran |website=brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=18 August 2015}} === Ticketing === The club installed an electronic ticketing system on all [[turnstile]]s at Griffin Park in the summer of 2014.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/august/match-day-ticket-arrangements-201415/ |title=Information from supporters on ticketing and access for Brentford FC match days at Griffin Park |last=Wickham |first=Chris |access-date=27 November 2014}} Previously, supporters were able to pay on the turnstiles on match days for non-all-ticket matches. ==Stadium structure== [[File:Griffin Park Ealing Road stand May 2005.jpg|thumb|[[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] supporters on the uncovered Ealing Road terrace during the [[2005 Football League play-offs#League One|2005 League One playoffs]]. A temporary [[Sky Sports]] TV gantry is located at the back of the stand.]] When first opened, Griffin Park had no [[Terrace (stadium)|terracing]] and banks surrounded the pitch, covered with ashes. A tiny stand was erected, which was initially refused a safety certificate. === Stands === * '''Braemar Road Stand''' – A two-tiered all-seated stand located along the Braemar Road,{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/tickets/stadium-plan/ |title=Stadium Plan |last=Brentford |website=www.brentfordfc.co.uk |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161224221447/http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/tickets/stadium-plan/ |archive-date=24 December 2016 |dead-url=yes |access-date=18 August 2015}} with the lower tier being known as 'the Paddock'.{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/documents/73374-brentford-fc-stadium-map-update-final-no-icons277-1652461.pdf |title=Brentford FC Stadium Map |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129024557/http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/documents/73374-brentford-fc-stadium-map-update-final-no-icons277-1652461.pdf |archive-date=29 November 2016 |dead-url=yes}} The stand also houses the dressing rooms, supporters' bar and club offices.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2015/june/want-to-sit-in-the-braemar-road-stand/ |title=Pick up your 2014/15 Sky Bet Championship season ticket in the Braemar Road stand |website=www.brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=23 October 2015}} The stand's forecourt houses the club shop and ticket office.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2012/august/bees-superstore-information/ |title=Bees superstore information |website=www.brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=23 October 2015}} Until 2010, the dugouts were located in front of the stand.{{cite web|last=Amos |first=Stuart |url=http://www.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/sport/football/4756684.Bees_bench_behind_Griffin_Park_stalemate/ |title=Bees bench behind Griffin Park stalemate (From Your Local Guardian) |publisher=Yourlocalguardian.co.uk |date=24 November 2009 |accessdate=15 August 2014}} * '''New Road Stand''' – A single-tiered all-seated stand located along the New Road. It is currently known as the Bill Axbey Stand, as a tribute to the club's oldest-ever supporter.{{cite web|url=http://www.richmondandtwickenhamtimes.co.uk/news/1377352.bill_axbey_the_legend_of_griffin_park_dies_aged_102/ |title=Bill Axbey: the legend of Griffin Park dies, aged 102 (From Richmond and Twickenham Times) |publisher=Richmondandtwickenhamtimes.co.uk |date=8 May 2007 |accessdate=}} The away supporters' section was housed in the northwest corner of the stand until October 1991.{{Cite book|title=The Big Brentford Book Of The Nineties|last=Croxford|first=Mark|last2=Lane|first2=David|last3=Waterman|first3=Greville|publisher=Legends Publishing|year=2013|isbn=9781906796723|location=Sunbury, Middlesex|page=83}} Previously a terrace, the stand was converted to seating in the summer of 1996.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 66}} The dugouts have been located in front of the stand since 2010 at the request of then-manager [[Andy Scott (English footballer)|Andy Scott]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~2044428,00.html |title=Brentford {{!}} News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} DUG OUTS |date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=24 March 2017}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~2052366,00.html |title=Brentford {{!}} News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} DUG OUTS UPDATE |date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=24 March 2017}} The central camera position for TV broadcasts of games is located in a gantry suspended from the roof of the stand.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2016/august/club-statement-on-new-road-gantry/ |title=Brentford FC club statement on the New Road Gantry Position at Griffin Park |last=FC |first=Brentford |access-date=15 August 2016}} The Family Section is located in blocks N506, N507 and N508. * '''Ealing Road Terrace''' – A single-tier terrace located at the Ealing Road end of the ground. Previously uncovered, the club had an application to build a roof turned down in 2004 and the terrace finally received a roof in 2007.{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2319906/Terry-Butcher-builds-on-solid-start-at-Brentford.html |title=Terry Butcher builds on solid start at Brentford |last=Football |date=27 August 2007 |publisher=Telegraph |access-date=13 August 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordtw8.com/default.asp?section=info&page=ebfc24.htm|title=Brentford's Local Web site|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2014}} Traditionally a home end, the terrace housed away supporters at various times throughout the 2000s.{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~1003068,00.html |title=Brentford {{!}} News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} BEES TO SWITCH ENDS |date=28 March 2007 |website=brentfordfc.co.uk |accessdate=8 April 2018}} * '''Brook Road Stand''' – A two-tiered stand with seating on the upper level and terracing on the lower level, built in the mid-1980s to replace the Royal Oak Stand (Griffin Park's 'kop').{{Cite web |url=http://beesotted.com/?p=252 |title=The Royal Oak Stand |publisher=Beesotted |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908063826/http://beesotted.com/?p=252 |archive-date=8 September 2017 |dead-url=yes |accessdate=13 August 2014}} At varying times the stand has housed home supporters (1980s, 2001–2007) or away supporters (1980s, 2007–present) and because of its appearance is affectionately known as 'the Wendy House'.{{Cite book|title=TW8 The Official Brentford FC Matchday Programme versus Tranmere Rovers 08/09/01|last=|first=|publisher=The Yellow Printing Company Limited|year=|isbn=|location=London|page=|pages=16–17|quote=|via=}} Until 2004, a [[vane display]] scoreboard was mounted on the stand's facade. === Floodlights === Brentford was one of the first clubs to recognise the potential of [[Floodlight#Association football|floodlit football]] and in 1954, a sum of £5,345 was spent on erecting perimeter lights the length of the Braemar Road and New Road stands.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 52}} With the [[The Football League|Football League]] banning competitive games under floodlights, a number of [[friendly matches]] were arranged to increase revenue, with one match against an International Managers XI attracting 21,600 spectators.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 52}} By the time the Football League's ban on competitive floodlit football was lifted in February 1956, the club had received over £10,000 in gate receipts from the friendly matches. The original perimeter lights were replaced in August 1963 with pylons located at each corner of the ground,{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 52}} at a cost of £17,000.{{Sfn|White|1989|p=21-23}} The current floodlight lamps on the pylons were purchased from [[West London derby|West London neighbours]] [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 1983.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 52}} Electronic scoreboards have been attached to two of the pylons since 2004.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2013/may/new-scoreboards-installed/ |title=New Scoreboards Installed |publisher=Brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=15 August 2014}} The floodlights were upgraded from 590 to 1000 [[lux]] during the 2015 off-season.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2015/june/alan-walsh-updates-on-griffin-park-improvements/ |title=Brentford FC Operations Manager Alan Walsh updates supporters on Griffin Park improvements |last=Wickham |first=Chris |website=www.brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=8 June 2015}} [[File:Griffin Park 1982 - geograph-2023521.jpg|thumb|right|Griffin Park in 1982, with the New Road Stand visible.]] == Attendances == === Records === * Record attendance (all competitions) – 38,678 versus [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], FA Cup sixth round, 24 February 1949) * Record attendance (Football League) – 38,535 versus [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], [[Football League First Division|First Division]], 8 September 1938) *Record attendance ([[Football League Cup|League Cup]]) – 17,859 versus [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], second round, first leg, 5 October 1983){{Cite book|title=The Big Brentford Book of the Eighties|last=Croxford|first=Mark|last2=Lane|first2=David|last3=Waterman|first3=Greville|publisher=Legends Publishing|year=2011|isbn=978-1906796716|location=Sunbury, Middlesex|page=100|quote=|via=}} * Record average attendance in a season – 27,716 ([[1936–37 Brentford F.C. season|1936–37]], First Division) * Highest attendance in division – 13,300 ([[1932–33 Brentford F.C. season|1932–33]], [[Football League Third Division South|Third Division South]]), 11,738 ([[1971–72 Brentford F.C. season|1971–72]], [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]]) === Recent years === As of 2016, Griffin Park has a capacity of 12,573.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/fans-and-community/first-time-visitors/ |title=First visit to Griffin Park? |last=FC |first=Brentford |website=www.brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=4 May 2017}} The highest attendance for a league match in recent seasons was 12,367 versus [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on 21 April 2018.{{Cite web|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/fixtures/first-team/201718/april/brentford-vs-queens-park-rangers-on-21-apr-18/#|title=Brentford vs Queens Park Rangers on 21 Apr 18 – Match Centre – Brentford FC|website=www.brentfordfc.com|language=en-gb|access-date=11 November 2018}} FA Cup fourth and fifth round matches versus [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] and [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] drew crowds of 11,698 and 11,720 in 2006 and 2005 respectively.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/4634288.stm |title=BBC SPORT | Football | FA Cup | Brentford 2–1 Sunderland |publisher=BBC News |date=28 January 2006 |accessdate=13 August 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/4300391.stm |title=BBC SPORT | Football | FA Cup | Brentford 1–3 Southampton |publisher=BBC News |date=1 March 2005 |accessdate=13 August 2014}} ==Neutral venue== [[File:Griffin_Park,_Brentford,_August_2011.jpg|thumb|Brentford and [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]] contesting a [[Corner kick|corner]] in front of the roofed Ealing Road stand in August 2011.]] === Football matches === * 1942 – [[Netherlands national football friendly matches in 1994 and 2000 respectively. Griffin Park hosted more [[FA Amateur Cup]] semi-finals than any other ground, with nine matches played between 1947 and 1974. === Tenants === * In 2002, [[London Broncos#2006–2011: Harlequins Rugby League|London Broncos]] [[rugby league]] team moved to Griffin Park.{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~152298,00.html |title=Brentford {{!}} News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} BRONCOS IN DEAL WITH BEES |website=brentfordfc.co.uk |accessdate=11 February 2018}} The club stayed at Griffin Park until the 2006 season, when it was re-branded [[London Broncos#2006–2011: Harlequins Rugby League|Harlequins RL]] and moved to [[Twickenham Stoop|The Stoop]]. The Broncos had earlier played two [[Rugby Football League Championship|Rugby League Championship]] matches at Griffin Park during the [[1995–96 Rugby Football League season|1995–96]] season.{{Cite book |title=A-Z Of Bees: Brentford Encyclopaedia |last=Haynes |first=Graham |date=1998 |publisher=Yore Publications |isbn=1 874427 57 7 |page=65}} * [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea's]] [[Chelsea F.C. Reserves and Academy|reserve and youth teams]] played their home games at Griffin Park from the beginning of the [[2007–08 Premier Reserve League|2007–08]] season until the end of [[2009–10 Premier Reserve League|2009–10]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~1023980,00.html |title=BLUES AND BEES ALLIANCE {{!}} Brentford {{!}} News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} Latest News |date=24 August 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2016}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~2032758,00.html |title=Brentford {{!}} News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} CHELSEA MOVE ON |website=brentfordfc.co.uk |accessdate=13 February 2018}} This agreement included the upgrading of the home dressing rooms in 2007. The reserve team returned to Griffin Park for a number of fixtures during the [[2012–13 Professional U21 Development League|2012–13]] season.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2012/august/chelsea-under-21s-to-use-griffin-park-/ |title=CHELSEA UNDER-21s TO USE GRIFFIN PARK |access-date=27 November 2014}} * [[Rugby union]] club [[London Welsh RFC|London Welsh]] considered moving to Griffin Park in 2012, but ultimately moved to the [[Kassam Stadium]] in [[Oxford]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/premiership-2011-12/rugby/story/164076.html |title=Championship: London Welsh announce Kassam Stadium switch | Live Rugby News | ESPN Scrum |publisher=Espn.co.uk |date= |accessdate=13 August 2014}} === Other sports === The first ever paying event at Griffin Park was a sports meeting on 29 July 1904, which included a [[wrestling]] match.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 18}} [[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]], [[tennis]] and [[Gaelic football]] have also taken place at the ground.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 18}} The [[Heinz]] baseball team played at the ground in the late 1900s, gaining admittance to the [[National Baseball League of Great Britain and Ireland]].{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 18}} == Advertising == [[File:Griffin Park, summer 1995.jpg|thumb|Griffin Park pictured from the [[London Heathrow Airport|Heathrow]] flightpath in 1995, with a [[KLM]] advertisement visible on the roof of the New Road stand.]] Griffin Park is beneath the flightpath of [[London Heathrow Airport]] and the roofs of the New Road and Braemar Road stands are used as a large advertising space. The roofs of both stands have been used to advertise [[KLM]], [[Ericsson]], [[Infogrames Entertainment, SA|Infogrames]] and [[Qatar Airways]].{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordtw8.com/default.asp?section=info&page=ebfc21.htm |title=Brentford's Local Web site |publisher=Brentfordtw8.com |date= |accessdate=15 August 2014}} The New Road Stand roof is currently sponsored by Matchbook, the club's official betting partner.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/july/brentford-announce-partnership-with-matchbook.com/ |title=Brentford Football Club agree deal with Matchbook.com to be Official Betting Partner |publisher=Brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=14 August 2014}} In the late 2000s, the Braemar Road stand was sponsored by [[water cooler]] business Refreshing Solutions.{{cite web|author=Football |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2329793/Brentford-notch-refreshing-win.html |title=Brentford notch refreshing win |publisher=Telegraph |date=31 December 2007 |accessdate=15 August 2014}} == "A pub on every corner" == Griffin Park is well known in football circles for being the only football ground in England to have a [[pub]] on each corner.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/travel/interactive/2013/mar/15/brentford-football-club-pub-each-corner-interactive|title=Brentford: probably the most refreshing football ground in the world – interactive | Travel|date=15 March 2013|publisher=theguardian.com|access-date=15 August 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/documents/griffin-park-guide277-1076877.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140630180955/http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/documents/griffin-park-guide277-1076877.pdf |archivedate=30 June 2014 |title=Griffin Park Guide |deadurl=yes }} The pubs are: * The Griffin – Located at the corner of Braemar Road and Brook Road.{{cite web|url=http://griffinbrentford.co.uk/ |title=The Griffin – Home |publisher=Griffinbrentford.co.uk |date=15 September 2013 |accessdate=15 August 2014}} The interior and exterior of the pub was used as a location in the 2005 film ''[[Green Street (film)|Green Street]]'' and is also visible in the 1954 film ''[[The Rainbow Jacket]]''.{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~515421,00.html |title=Brentford {{!}} News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} ELIJAH AT GRIFFIN PARK! |date=19 April 2004 |website=brentfordfc.co.uk |accessdate=19 February 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordhistory.com/connections/tv-and-film/griffin-from-ealing-studios-the-rainbow-jacket-1954/ |title=The Rainbow Jacket, 1954, The Griffin | The History of Brentford |publisher=Brentfordhistory.com |date=3 January 2014 |accessdate=15 August 2014}} * The Princess Royal – Located at the corner of Braemar Road and Ealing Road.{{cite web|url=http://princessroyalbrentford.co.uk/ |title=The Princess Royal – Home |publisher=Princessroyalbrentford.co.uk |date=15 September 2013 |accessdate=15 August 2014}} * The New Inn – Located at the corner of New Road and Ealing Road.{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordhistory.com/2013/04/26/the-new-inn/|title=The New Inn|last=Kath|date=26 April 2013|website=The History of Brentford|access-date=13 July 2016}} * The Royal Oak – Located at the corner of New Road and Brook Road.{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordhistory.com/2013/04/26/the-royal-oak/|title=The Royal Oak|last=Kath|date=26 April 2013|website=The History of Brentford|access-date=13 July 2016}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.wellingtonpubcompany.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/3191111-Royal-Oak-Brentford.pdf |title=Royal Oak, Brentford – Wellington Pub Company |accessdate=14 June 2018}} == Appearances in media == Due to its convenient location in West London, Griffin Park has featured in a number of films, TV programmes and advertisements: * ''[[The Winning Goal]]'' (film, 1920) – Footage was shot of a specially staged match between fictional teams Blacktown and Bichester, with both teams featuring 16 then-current international players.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 30}}{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0164233/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1|title=The Winning Goal (1920)|date=1 August 1920|work=IMDb|accessdate=18 August 2015}} * ''[[The Great Game (1953 film)|The Great Game]]'' (film, 1954) – Scenes were shot in and around the ground and during matches.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 30}} * ''[[Minder (TV series)|Minder]]'' (''The Long Ride Back to Scratchwood'', TV, 1984) – The interior of the ground was used for football training scenes.{{cite book |last= |first= |year=1995 |title=Brentford F.C. Griffin Gazette versus Stockport County 11/03/95 |url= |location= |publisher=Quay Design of Poole |page=33|isbn= |accessdate= }} * ''[[Standing Room Only (1991 TV programme)|Standing Room Only]]'' (TV, 1991) – The interior of the ground was featured in a sketch, with an emphasis on two of the club's main sponsors at the time, [[KLM Royal Dutch Airlines|KLM]] and Bollingmores Car Distributors.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 30}} * ''[[Goal! (film)|Goal!]]'' (film, 2005) – Griffin Park featured as [[Newcastle United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Newcastle United Reserves]]' home ground.{{Cite web |url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk.p.preprod.performgroup.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~621301,00.html |title=Brentford {{!}} News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} Latest News {{!}} GOAL! |date=1 February 2005 |website=brentfordfc.co.uk |accessdate=20 February 2018}}{{Citation |title=Goal! The Dream Begins (2005) |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0380389/locations |accessdate=20 February 2018}} * ''[[Mike Bassett: Manager]]'' (TV, 2005) – Griffin Park doubled as the home ground of the series' fictitious team Wirral County. All Brentford-inscribed signs and notices were replaced around the ground with Wirral County equivalents.{{cite book |last= |first= |year=2005 |title=Brentford Football Club Official Matchday Magazine versus Hull City 07/05/05 |url= |location= |pages=54, 55|isbn= |accessdate= }} ==Ownership== The original lease on the ground ran out in 1925, but the deal was kept on ice and the club became freeholders in April 1936.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 66}} With Brentford in the [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]] and heavily in debt in the late 1960s, in March 1968 [[Jim Gregory (football chairman)|Jim Gregory]] (chairman of West London rivals Queens Park Rangers) offered £250,000 to buy the ground and move Queens Park Rangers to Griffin Park.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 123-125}} Former Brentford chairman Walter Wheatley stepped in and provided the club with a £69,000 loan.{{Sfn|Haynes|1998|p = 123-125}} In 1998, then-chairman [[Ron Noades]] acquired the freehold of Griffin Park, through his company Griffin Park Stadium Limited.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/brentford/1194658.stm |title=BBC SPORT | BRENTFORD | Brentford may share with Woking |publisher=BBC News |date=2 March 2001 |accessdate=14 August 2014}} With Noades declaring he would only fund the club until 2000,{{cite web|author=Leo Spall |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/brentford-get-set-for-move-to-woking-6356972.html |title=Brentford get set for move to Woking – Sport – London Evening Standard |publisher=Standard.co.uk |date=15 January 2001 |accessdate=14 August 2014}} the prospect of the sale of Griffin Park for development looked likely until 2006, when supporters' trust Bees United bought his majority shareholding. Noades' loans to the club were repaid by current owner Matthew Benham in 2007.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2013/december/ron-noades-1937-2013/ |title=RON NOADES 1937–2013 |date=24 December 2013 |publisher=Brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=14 August 2014}} == Future == {{Main|Brentford Community Stadium}} === Brentford Community Stadium === In August 1973, the ''[[Middlesex Chronicle]]'' reported that the club had submitted a bid to [[Hounslow Council]] to build a new ground and leisure complex on the site of Brentford Market.{{cite book |last= |first= |year=2002 |title=TW8: The Home Of Football – Brentford FC versus Bristol City 13/08/02 |url= |location= Charlton, London|publisher=The Yellow Printing Company |isbn= |page=33|accessdate= }} Brentford's hopes of moving to a new 20,000-capacity stadium were boosted in 2007 after the club was given an option to buy a {{convert|7.6|acre|m2|sing=on}} site at Lionel Road, less than a mile away from Griffin Park.{{cite web |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/other-sport/barratt-homes-pull-out-new-5990462 |title=Barratt Homes pull out on new Brentford stadium deal |last=Street |first=Tim |date=28 January 2011 |publisher=Get West London |access-date=14 August 2014}} The project was halted in 2010 due to the [[Great Recession|economic downturn]] and partners Barratt Homes pulled out of the deal in January 2011. In June 2012, the club bought the Lionel Road site from Barratt Homes.{{cite web|title = Brentford ground plans take step forward|url = http://www.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/news/local/richmondnews/9790628.Brentford_ground_plans_take_step_forward/?ref=rss|website = Your Local Guardian|accessdate = 9 September 2015}} Outline planning approval was given by the [[London Borough of Hounslow]] on 5 December 2013, with the [[Mayor of London|Mayor of London's]] office giving their approval in February 2014.{{Cite web |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/local-news/brentford-fcs-new-lionel-road-6832603 |title=Brentford FC's new Lionel Road stadium gets the final thumbs up |last=Culbertson |first=Alix |date=14 March 2014 |publisher=Get West London |accessdate=14 August 2014}} [[Eric Pickles]] (then-[[Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government]]) gave final approval for the stadium on 14 March 2014 and a development agreement was signed with [[Willmott Dixon]] in December 2014.{{Cite web |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2014/december/new-stadium-progress-as-agreement-signed-/ |title=Brentford FC and Willmott Dixon sign Development Agreement for Brentford Community Stadium at Lionel Road South |last=FC |first=Brentford |website=www.brentfordfc.co.uk |access-date=8 June 2015}} The commencement of work on the Lionel Road site was held up through 2015 due to First Industrial Ltd (which owned the final parcel of land needed to begin development) objecting to a [[compulsory purchase order]] by Hounslow Council.{{cite web|title = Brentford FC being 'held to ransom' over new stadium|url = http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/west-london-news/brentford-fc-being-held-ransom-10015670|accessdate = 9 September 2015|first = Robert|last = Cumber}} Hounslow Council completed the acquisition of the land in September 2016 and on-site preparation for construction began in late March 2017.{{Cite news |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2016/september/completion-of-compulsory-purchase-order-process-for-the-brentford-community-stadium/ |title=Hounslow Council now in possession of land required for new Brentford Community Stadium at Lionel Road South |last=FC |first=Brentford |access-date=2 January 2017}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/march/brentford-community-stadium-work-starts-at-lionel-road-south/ |title=Work begins on Brentford Community Stadium at Lionel Road South |last=FC |first=Brentford |access-date=24 March 2017 |language=en}} [[Groundbreaking|Ground was broken]] at the site on 19 March 2018 and as of August 2018,{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2018/march/ground-breaking-19.03.18/|title=Brentford FC’s new stadium ground-breaking ceremony – News – Brentford FC|access-date=2 April 2018|language=en-gb}} the club is expected to move into the stadium during the 2020 off-season.{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2018/august/stadium-update-28.08.18|title=Brentford FC to move home in summer 2020 as work continues on new stadium|access-date=28 August 2018|language=en-gb}} === Griffin Park === Brentford's 5th-place finish in the Championship playoff places in the [[2014–15 Brentford F.C. season|2014–15]] season raised questions about Griffin Park's suitability for Premier League football,{{cite web |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/brentford-plan-griffin-park-stay-8183468 |title=Brentford plan for Griffin Park stay in Premier League |last=Tim Street |website=getwestlondon |access-date=27 November 2014}} prior to the then-expected move to the [[Brentford Community Stadium|Community Stadium]] in 2017. Chief executive Mark Devlin explained that should improvements to Griffin Park to meet Premier League standards not be viable, Brentford would look to [[groundshare]] with another club in the vicinity. By May 2015, [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], [[Wembley Stadium]] and [[Twickenham Stoop]] were ruled out as potential venues and West London neighbours Queens Park Rangers and Fulham refused to comment.{{cite web |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/brentford-will-spend-3m-to-upgrade-griffin-park-but-could-groundshare-with-qpr-if-club-secures-premier-league-promotion-10228537.html |title=Brentford will spend £3m to upgrade Griffin Park but could |website=Evening Standard |access-date=18 August 2015}} In May 2015, it was revealed that it would cost £3 million to upgrade Griffin Park to meet Premier League specifications. On 3 September 2015, Hounslow Council approved the building of 75 new homes on the site of Griffin Park, after the club moves out.{{cite web|title = Brentford FC stadium to be replaced by family homes|url = http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/west-london-news/new-homes-approved-brentford-fcs-9989213|accessdate = 9 September 2015|first = Robert|last = Cumber}} Brentford were given special dispensation by the [[Sports Grounds Safety Authority|Sports Ground Safety Authority]] to retain the terracing in the Ealing Road and Brook Road stands for the 2017–18 and [[2018–19 Brentford F.C. season|2018–19]] seasons, due to the club's good safety record over the previous seasons in the Championship and its impending move to the Community Stadium.{{Cite news |url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2017/march/club-given-approval-to-retain-terracing-at-griffin-park/ |title=Brentford given dispensation to retain Terracing at Griffin Park for 2017/18 Sky Bet Championship season |last=Brett |first=Ciaran |access-date=9 March 2017 |language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.brentfordfc.com/news/2018/june/terracing-retained-june-2018/|title=Brentford FC given permission to retain terracing for 2018/19|access-date=14 June 2018|language=en-gb}} In October 2018, it was reported that the 2019–20 season would be Brentford's last at Griffin Park.{{Cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/brentford-hoping-to-play-final-season-at-griffin-park-if-they-are-promoted-to-premier-league-a3957386.html |title=Brentford hoping to play final season at Griffin Park if they are promoted |last=Muro |first=Giuseppe |work=Evening Standard |accessdate=9 October 2018 |language=en-GB}} Should promotion to the Premier League be achieved at the end of the 2018–19 season, the club will apply for special dispensation to play the 2019–20 Premier League season at Griffin Park. ==See also== *[[Ground improvements at English football Stadia]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commonscatinline}} * {{mmukscaled|517950_177900|10000|Map sources}} for Griffin Park can be seen as a square on the west side of Ealing Road (i.e. left side on the map). It may be labelled ''Brentford FC'' rather than Griffin Park. {{Brentford F.C.}} {{Football League Championship Venues}} {{London Broncos}} {{1948 Summer Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues football}} [[Category:Venues of the 1948 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Brentford F.C.]] [[Category:Brentford, London]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in the London Borough of Hounslow]] [[Category:Chelsea F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in London]] [[Category:Olympic football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1904]] [[Category:Defunct rugby league venues in England]] [[Category:London Broncos]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in the London Borough of Hounslow]] [[Category:English Football League venues]]

revision.text:
{{infobox organization | name = International Council of Yacht Clubs (ICOYC) | image = | caption = | formation = 2005 | location = | leader_title = Commodores’ Forum | leader_name = | coor = | campus = | free_label = Tag line | free = | status = active | purpose = advocate and public voice, educator and network for [[Recreational boating]], and competitive sailors, coaches, volunteers and events; improve the quality of the services yacht clubs provide to their members, as well as promoting environmental awareness and responsibility towards the environment. | language = [[English language|English]] | colours = | nickname = | publictransit = | affiliations = | website = }} The '''International Council of Yacht Clubs''' (ICOYC) is an international organization that operates at the level of [[Commodore (yacht club)|Commodore]]s of [[yacht clubs]] through a '''Commodores’ Forum'''.
Its vision is to improve the quality of the services yacht clubs provide to their members, as well as promoting environmental awareness and responsibility towards the environment.
Among its practical objectives, the main thrust is to identify areas of interest and areas of concern among member clubs and to share information and experience on these areas. The ICOYC also would like to promote fellowship and informal contact among member clubs by means of sailing events as well as social activities. ==Membership== {{AP|List of International Council of Yacht Clubs members}} The membership of the ICOYC is composed of prestigious yacht clubs in key yachting locations around the world, from Africa to Asia and the Pacific. Its main members are: [[Royal Natal Yacht Club]], [[Annapolis Yacht Club]], [[Chicago Yacht Club]], [[Eastern Yacht Club]], [[Long Beach Yacht Club]], [[Newport Harbor Yacht Club]], [[Royal Canadian Yacht Club]], [[Royal Vancouver Yacht Club]], [[San Diego Yacht Club]], [[San Francisco Yacht Club]], [[Seattle Yacht Club]], [[Southern Yacht Club]], [[St. Francis Yacht Club]], [[Republic of Singapore Yacht Club]], [[Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club]], [[Royal Varuna Yacht Club]], [[Royal Freshwater Bay Yacht Club]], [[Royal New Zealand Yacht Squadron]], [[Royal Perth Yacht Club]], [[Royal Queensland Yacht Squadron]], [[Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron]], [[Sandringham Yacht Club]], [[Bruxelles Royal Yacht Club]], [[Clube Naval de Cascais]], [[Gstaad Yacht Club]], [[Royal Danish Yacht Club]], [[Royal Norwegian Yacht Club]], [[Royal Swedish Yacht Club]], [[Norddeutscher Regatta Verein]], [[Nyländska Jaktklubben]], [[Royal Cork Yacht Club]], [[Royal Malta Yacht Club]], [[Société Nautique de Marseille]], [[Verein Seglerhaus am Wannsee]], [[Yacht Club Italiano]] and [[Royal Southern Yacht Club]].<ref>[http://www.icoyc.org/Default.aspx?p=DynamicModule&pageid=313682&ssid=203559&vnf=1 Member list]</ref>
==History== Its origins can be traced to [[Canada]], where there was a discussion at the Royal Vancouver Yacht Club (RVYC) in 2003 about the need of an international Yacht Club organization. Practical steps were taken in 2005 when the RVYC hosted the first Commodores’ Forum, attended by representatives of yacht clubs around the world.
The International Council of Yacht Clubs was finally established in 2006 in [[Hong Kong]], when the Royal Hong Kong Yacht Club hosted the second Commodores’ Forum. This event was attended by 28 yacht clubs from five continents.
==See also== * [[Royal Yachting Association]] * [[Watersports]] * [[Yachting]] * [[List of International Council of Yacht Clubs members]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2010}} [[File:Ki on grass1.jpg|thumb|A traditional kī-o-rahi ball.]] '''Kī-o-rahi''' is a ball [[sport]] played in [[New Zealand]] with a small round ball called a 'kī'. It is a fast-paced game incorporating skills similar to [[rugby union]], [[netball]] and [[Touch football (rugby league)|touch]].<ref name="odt">Shane Gilchrist, [http://innz.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?BBID=533353 'Game on, the "ki" is back in court'] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130920185818/http://innz.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?BBID=533353 |date=20 September 2013 }}, ''[[Otago Daily Times]]'', 5 October 2007</ref> Two teams of seven players play on a circular field divided into zones, and score points by touching the 'pou' (boundary markers) and hitting a central 'tupu' or target.<ref name="odt"/><ref name="jones">{{Cite web|author=Jones, Renee |date=October 8, 2005 |title=McDonald's adopts obscure Maori ball game |work=[[New Zealand Herald]] |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&ObjectID=10349245|accessdate=2007-07-30 }}</ref> The game is played with varying rules (e.g. number of people, size of field, tag ripping rules etc.) depending on the geographic area it is played in. A process called Tatu, before the game, determines which rules the two teams will use.
In 2005 kī-o-rahi was chosen to represent New Zealand by global fast-food chain [[McDonald's]] as part of its 'Passport to Play' programme to teach physical play activities in 31,000 American schools.<ref name="jones"/><ref>{{Cite web|title=McDonald's Passport to Play Kicks Off in 31,000 Schools |work=McDonald's Electronic Press Kit |url=http://www.mcdepk.com/passporttoplay/ |accessdate=2007-07-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026064120/http://www.mcdepk.com/passporttoplay/ |archivedate=26 October 2007 |df= }}</ref> The programme will give instruction in 15 ethnic games to seven million primary school children.<ref name="jones"/>
The New Zealand kī-o-rahi representative organisation, ''Kī-o-Rahi Akotanga Iho'', formed with men's and women's national teams, completed a 14 match tour of Europe in September and October 2010. The men's team included 22-test [[All Black]] veteran [[Wayne Shelford]] who led the team to a 57–10 test win against Kī-o-Rahi Dieppe Organisation, the French Kī-o-Rahi federation. Shelford's kī-o-rahi test jersey made him the first kī-o-rahi/rugby double international for NZ. The women's team coached by Andrea Cameron (Head of PE at Tikipunga High School) also won by 33–0. These were the first historic test matches between NZ and France.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northlandage.co.nz/sports.php?news_id=3605 |title=Historic tour grabs another win |work=Northland Age |accessdate=2011-02-02 |date=2010-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724193440/http://www.northlandage.co.nz/sports.php?news_id=3605 |archivedate=24 July 2011 }}</ref>
==Origins== Although former chief executive of the [[Māori Language Commission]], Dr. [[Patu Hohepa]], a noted Māori academic, was quoted as saying "We cannot track it in the traditional Maori world... at this present time it is a mystery." Nonetheless he found the idea (that this was a traditional game) "fabulously exciting".<ref name="jones"/> According to Henry Anderson, kaiwhakahaere (Māori sport co-ordinator) for Sport Northland, kī-o-rahi is a traditional Māori game that has been "handed down over the centuries". Harko Brown, a physical education teacher at [[Kerikeri High School]], who was taught the game in the late 1970s on his [[marae]] in the south [[Waikato]], described it as "an indigenous game imbued with [[tikanga Māori]] with a very long history ... of a pre-European nature." References to the ancient forms of the game can be found in his book ''Nga Taonga Takaro''.<ref name="brown">{{cite book | title=Nga Taonga Takaro: Maori Sports & Games | publisher=[[Penguin Books (NZ)]] | author=Brown, Harko | year=2008 | isbn=9780143009702}}</ref> It is not clear when the term 'kī-o-rahi' originated as a collective term for ancient ball games played around a tupu.
It is said to be based on the legend of Rahitutakahina and the rescue of his wife, Tiarakurapakewai.<ref name="Traditional Maori games">{{cite news|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/206322/traditional-maori-games-making-comeback|title=Traditional Maori games making a comeback|last=Lewis|first=John|date=21 Apr 2012|work=Otago Daily Times|accessdate=19 September 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Team Sport|state=collapsed}}

{{flagIOC|URS}} (1952–1988) }} '''[[Latvia]]''' competed at the '''[[1992 Winter Olympics]]''' in [[Albertville]], [[France]]. It was the first time since [[Latvia at the 1936 Winter Olympics|1936]] that the nation had competed as an independent nation at the [[Winter Olympic Games]].
