2006-07 | 17,541 | [[Football League Championship]] |{{cite web |url= http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Attendance/0,,10794~200510323,00.html |title= Crystal Palace Attendance 2006–07 |accessdate= 23 October 2013 |publisher= The Football League |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130728191336/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Attendance/0,,10794~200510323,00.html |archivedate= 28 July 2013 |df= dmy-all }} |- ! 2005-06 | 19,457 | [[Football League Championship]] |{{cite web |url= http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Attendance/0,,10794~200410323,00.html |title= Crystal Palace Attendance 2005–06 |accessdate= 23 October 2013 |publisher= The Football League |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140426201647/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Attendance/0,,10794~200410323,00.html |archivedate= 26 April 2014 |df= dmy-all }} |- ! 2004-05 | 24,108 | [[Premier League]] |{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Attendance/0,,10794~200310323,00.html |title=Crystal Palace Attendance 2004–05 |accessdate=23 October 2013 |publisher=Premier League |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130728191212/http://www.football-league.co.uk/page/Attendance/0,,10794~200310323,00.html |archivedate=28 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }} |} === Records === The record attendance in Selhurst Park was achieved in 1979 when 51,801 people saw Crystal Palace defeat [[Burnley F.C.]] 2–0 to clinch the [[Football League Second Division]] championship title. The ground also holds the record for [[Football League Fourth Division|Division Four]] (now [[Football League Two|League Two]] in the [[English football league system|English football pyramid]]) attendance when Crystal Palace played local rivals [[Millwall F.C.]] in 1961 after 37,774 people turned out for the game.{{cn|date=September 2018}} Selhurst Park recorded the lowest attendance for a [[Premier League]] game - 3,039 during [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] v. [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 26 January 1993. The game finished 3-1 to Everton.{{cite web |url=http://web.orange.co.uk/article/gaffer/Lowest-attendances-in-all-divs |title=Lowest attendances in all divs|publisher=Orange|accessdate=23 October 2013}} ==See also== *[[List of English football stadia by capacity]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://www.cpfc.co.uk/club/visit-us/ Stadium information] at Crystal Palace FC official website * [http://img.skysports.com/08/07/480/Crystal-Palace--Selhurst-Park_1058249.jpg Stadium picture] {{Crystal Palace F.C.}} {{Premier League venues}} {{Croydon B&S}} {{1948 Summer Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues football}} [[Category:Venues of the 1948 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic football venues]] [[Category:Crystal Palace F.C.]] [[Category:Wimbledon F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in London]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in the London Borough of Croydon]] [[Category:Premier League venues]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in the London Borough of Croydon]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1924]] [[Category:English Football League venues]]

{{Football club infobox | clubname = Sokol Cholupice | image = [[Image:Sokol Cholpice logo.gif]] | fullname = Sokol Cholupice | nickname = | founded = 1924 | ground =
Hrazanská ul.
[[Prague 4]] – [[Cholupice]] | capacity = | chairman = | manager = Rudolf Kahle | league = [[Prague Championship]] | season = 2014–15 | position = 8th | |pattern_la1=_black_stripes|pattern_b1=_blackstripes4_2|pattern_ra1=_black_stripes |leftarm1=|body1=ffffff|rightarm1=|shorts1=000000|socks1=ffffff }} '''Sokol Cholupice''' is a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] [[association football|football]] club located in [[Prague]]-[[Cholupice]], [[Czech Republic]]. It played in the [[Prague Championship]], the fifth tier of the [[Czech Republic football league system|Czech football system]], until being relegated at the end of the 2010–11 season. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website}} {{cs icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120314140944/http://www.fotbalpraha.cz/sokol-cholupice/ Sokol Cholupice at the website of the Prague Football Association] {{cs icon}} {{CzechRepublic-footyclub-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sokol Cholupice}} [[Category:Football clubs in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Sport in Prague]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1924]] [[Category:Sokol]]

{{multiple issues| {{notability|date=April 2017}} {{refimprove|date=April 2017}} {{self-published|date=April 2017}} {{unreliable sources|date=April 2017}} }} Queensland's Sunshine Coast has sporting teams across national, state, and local levels. Some Coast based clubs trace their history back to the early 20th century.<ref name="history" />
The most recent club to be established on the Sunshine Coast is the [[Sunshine Coast Lightning]] who compete in the national [[Suncorp Super Netball]] competition.
== Sports == ===Australian rules football=== The [[Caloundra Australian Football Club|Caloundra Panthers]], [[Maroochydore Australian Football Club|Maroochydore Roos]] and [[Noosa AFC|Noosa Tigers]] all compete in the Queensland Football Associations division 1 competition alongside other South East Queensland clubs. The Hinterland Blues play in division 3 of the same competition.
Gympie and Pomona play in a competition with four [[Wide Bay–Burnett|Wide Bay]] clubs and Maroochydores 3rd XVIII.
===Cricket=== The [[Caloundra RSL Cup (cricket)|Sunshine Coast Cricket Association]] is the region's [[cricket]] competition. The competition has been established for over sixty years.<ref name="history">{{cite web |url= http://www.maroochydorecricketclub.com.au/AboutUs/AboutUs.htm |title= About Us |accessdate=2007-03-28 |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |year= |month= |work= |publisher= Maroochydore Cricket Club |pages= |language= |archiveurl= |archivedate= |quote=Maroochydore Cricket Club (MCC) has been established for over 60 years. }}</ref>
===Netball=== The Sunshine Coast region has several district netball competitions based out of Nambour, Maroochydore and Caloundra.
The [[Sunshine Coast Lightning]] compete in the [[Suncorp Super Netball]] league. They are the first national level sporting team based in the region, and play their home games at the [[University of the Sunshine Coast]]'s [[University of the Sunshine Coast#Netball stadium|indoor arena]].
===Soccer=== [[Sunshine Coast Football]] is the region's premier [[association football]] competition with nine teams in its top division. Other affiliated clubs play at lower levels.
There is also a churches competition played in the region.
The Sunshine Coast is currently represented in the state level [[National Premier League Queensland]] by [[Sunshine Coast FC]]. [[Sunshine Coast Wanderers FC]] will join the Queensland second tier from 2018 while the Fire will remain in the first tier NPL. It was reported in 2016 that the Fire were in the process of applying to join the national [[A-League]].<ref>[http://www.sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/coasts-a-league-bid-progresses-to-next-stage/3133244/ Sunshine Coast's A-League bid progresses to next stage]</ref>
===Rugby league=== The [[Sunshine Coast Falcons]] compete in the [[Queensland Cup]] and serve as a feeder club for the professional [[Melbourne Storm]] that compete in the [[National Rugby League]].
===Rugby union=== The [[Sunshine Coast Rugby Union]] runs the local [[rugby union]] competition. Its top division - referred to as A grade - has four teams contesting the 2017 season. These clubs are Noosa, Maroochydore, University, and Caloundra.<ref>{{cite AV media |people= Patrick Gillett |date= |title= SCRU 2017 |trans-title= |medium= online video |language= english |url= https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLocFZCkisZ8v5ybsROzy3rAWrirIvq4RY |access-date= June 6, 2017 |archive-url= |archive-date= |format= |time= |location= |publisher= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }}</ref>
The second division - reserve grade or reggies - has the four A grade clubs as well as Fraser Coast, Gympie, Nambour, and Maleny.
===Roller derby=== [[File:Rum city vs. CARD.webm|thumb|right|300px|Roller Derby is played out of the Caloundra Indoor Stadium.]] [[Coastal Assassins Roller Derby]] is a [[roller derby]] league based out of the Sunshine Coast. Most of their home games are played out of the Caloundra Indoor Stadium.
==Media== Local media regularly cover all four football codes and cricket. [[WIN News|Win]] and [[Seven News#Regional Queensland|Seven]]<ref>{{cite news|title=7 News Sunshine Coast – Sport 26/06/17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t5CqnlykrsA|accessdate=28 June 2017|work=7 News Sunshine Coast|publisher=Seven Queensland|date=26 June 2017}}</ref> provide a coverage in half hour bulletins during the week. The ''[[Sunshine Coast Daily]]'' does written coverage on Mondays and Fridays.
[[Wikinews]] has previously provided coverage of the Sunshine Coast Rugby Union,<ref>{{cite web|title=Sunshine Coast Rugby Union|url=https://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Category:Sunshine_Coast_Rugby_Union|website=Wikinews|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref> Coastal Assassins Roller Derby<ref name="Sunshine Coast" /> and Sunshine Coast Cricket Association.<ref name="Sunshine Coast">{{cite web|title=Sunshine Coast|url=https://en.wikinews.org/wiki/Category:Sunshine_Coast|website=Wikinews|accessdate=28 June 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Sport in the Sunshine Coast, Queensland]]
{{Australia-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = Stadsparksvallen | nickname = ''Vallen'' (The Pasture) | image = Stadsparksvallen.jpg | imagesize = 200px | caption = Stadsparksvallen in August 2008 | fullname = Stadsparksvallen | former_names = | location = Skjutsarbacken 12
SE-553 13 [[Jönköping]]
[[Sweden]] | coordinates = {{coord|57|46|59.88|N|14|08|30.71|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1902 | opened = 1902{{cite web |url=http://www.j-sodra.se/web/Stadsparksvallen.aspx |title=Stadsparksvallen |publisher=[[Jönköpings Södra IF]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2009-09-02}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Jönköping Municipality]] | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = Yes | construction_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 6,261 | record_attendance = 18,582 ([[Jönköpings Södra IF]] vs. [[Malmö FF]], final match of the [[1949–50 Allsvenskan]] season) | dimensions = 105 x 65 m | tenants = [[Jönköpings Södra IF]] ([[Allsvenskan]]) }} '''Stadsparksvallen''' (popularly called ''Vallen'') is a classic sports facility located in [[Jönköping]], [[Sweden]]. Stadsparksvallen was inaugurated in 1902 and is located in Jönköping's town park. ''Vallen'' functions as the [[football (soccer)|football]] club [[Jönköpings Södra IF]]'s home arena ([[IK Tord]] also plays here), but as late as 1981 it was used for [[track and field]] events. Jönköpings Södra IF has played 10 seasons in the Swedish [[Allsvenskan]] in Stadsparksvallen. Sweden women's national football team has played thrice at the venue, first time in 1985 against [[Belgium women's national football team|Belgium]].{{cite news |url=http://www.jnytt.se/nyhet/25133/stadsparksvallen-rustas-for-damlandskampen |title=Stadsparksvallen rustas för damlandskampen |newspaper=Jnytt.se |language=Swedish |date=2009-07-14 |accessdate=2009-09-02}} During the [[Swedish Sports Confederation]]'s 100th [[anniversary]] in 2003, Stadsparksvallen was designated as one of the 100 sports historic places in Sweden.{{cite web|title=100 idrotthistoriska platser |publisher=Riksidrottsförbundet |url=http://www.rf.se/rf100/files/%7BC7B813EC-3804-4AF1-BD58-938A59B1FEDE%7D.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |language=Swedish |accessdate=2006-04-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926235816/http://www.rf.se/rf100/files/%7BC7B813EC-3804-4AF1-BD58-938A59B1FEDE%7D.pdf |archivedate=September 26, 2007 }} ==Facts== * '''Dimensions''': 115 x 71 [[yards]] (105 x 65 meters) * '''Capacity''': 5,200, of which 1,413 seated (936 roofed) * '''Record attendance''': 18,582, [[Jönköpings Södra IF]] vs. [[Malmö FF]], final match during season 1949–50 in [[Allsvenskan]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commonscat-inline|Stadsparksvallen}} {{Jönköpings Södra IF}} {{Allsvenskan venues}} [[Category:Football venues in Sweden]] [[Category:Jönköpings Södra IF]] [[Category:Sports venues in Jönköping]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1902]] [[Category:1902 establishments in Sweden]]

{{For|the new Sydney Showground Speedway located at Homebush Bay|Sydney Showground (Homebush)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2011}} {{Motorsport venue | Name = Sydney Showground | Nicknames = Speedway Royale
Speedway Royal
The Royale | Image = [[File:Sydney Showground, Grand Parade Easter 1936 (14039813382).jpg|230px]] | caption = Sydney Showground during the 1936 [[Sydney Royal Easter Show]]. The speedways start/finish line was located at the right of the picture. | Location = [[Moore Park, New South Wales]] | Broke_ground = 1882 | Opened = 1882 (showground)
1926 (speedway) | Closed = 1996 | Coordinates = {{coord|33|53|36|S|151|13|37|E|display=it}} | Owner = [[New South Wales Government]] | Operator = [[Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales|Royal Agricultural Society of NSW]] (showground)
Empire Speedways (speedway) | Construction_cost = | Architect = | Former_names = | Events = [[Australian Sprintcar Championship]]
[[Australian Speedcar Championship]]
[[Australian Speedcar Grand Prix]]
[[Individual Speedway Australian Championship|Australian Solo Championship]]
[[Australian Sidecar Speedway Championship|Australian Sidecar Championship]]
[[Australasian Individual Speedway Championship|Australasian Solo Final]] | Capacity = 40,000 | Layout1 = Oval | Surface = dolomite | Miles_first = True | Length_mi = 0.316 | Length_km = 0.509 | Banking = | Record_time = 0:16.876 | Record_driver = [[Jay Drake]] ({{flagicon|USA}}) | Record_team = | Record_year = 1996 | Record_class = [[Midget car racing|Speedcar]] }} '''Sydney Showground Speedway''', originally known as the Speedway Royal and later the Speedway Royale but often referred to as just The Royale or The Showground, was a dirt [[Dirt track racing]] venue at the old [[Sydney Showground (Moore Park)|Sydney Showground]] used from 1926 until 1996. ==History== In 1937, The Showground was claimed to the fastest speedway in the world by the tracks promoters. The {{convert|509|m|yd|abbr=off}} egg shaped track was also the site of some spectacular crashes, some unfortunate deaths and a lot of spectacular racing. Although [[Motorcycle Speedway|solos]] were first to race at the showground on 21 July 1926, they were soon joined by [[Sidecar speedway|sidecars]] and [[Midget car racing|Speedcars]] (also known as Midgets but called Speedcars in Australia). In the 1950s [[stock cars]] began to appear joined much later by demolition derbies and jumping motorcycles over buses and the Royale would attract huge spectator attendance. The track had a dolomite surface, which the speedway drivers and riders continually asked the owners, the [[Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales|Royal Agricultural Society of NSW]], to mix in shale and clay (as used on tracks in [[England]] such as [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]]) to improve traction but this never happened. A long stated reason for this was that the Showground was also used year-round as a [[harness racing]] venue (though this excuse wore thin after the 'trotts' moved permanently to the [[Harold Park Paceway]] in the late 1940s). The only other major complaint about the track itself was that it was very narrow compared to other speedways. Where most tracks allowed three wide racing even in the corners, at the Showground there was barely enough room for two cars. The speedway's pits were located under the Martin & Angus Stand at the southern end of the track. This created a unique atmosphere with the place often filling with cigarette smoke and the smell of oil and petrol. Former dual Rugby international and part-time announcer at the speedway [[Rex Mossop]] once described the pits at the Royale as being like "Dantino's Inferno". The start / finish line at the Showground was on the eastern side of the track in front of the Suttor Stand. Running anti-clockwise as most speedway divisions do, the track then moved into the Bull Pens for turn 1, so called as this was where the cattle would enter the arena during the [[Sydney Royal Easter Show|Royal Easter Show]]. The track announcers box was located close to the track above the Bull Pens. They then continued past the double decked Members Stand and the famous clock tower sitting on the roof, and into what riders called "The Armpit", a tight turn leading onto the back straight where the Coronation Stand stood. Turns 3 and 4 went past Martin & Angus Stand and the pits before passing the Sinclair Stand in turn 4 and coming onto the main straight to finish the lap. Although the Showground was later universally known as a Speedcar track, from the late 1920s until the 1950s the speedway was more known for its motorcycle racing, hosting many [[Individual Speedway Australian Championship|Australian Solo Championship]] and [[Australian Sidecar Speedway Championship|Australian Sidecar Championship]] meetings as well as Solo test Matches between [[Australia national speedway team|Australia]] and various visiting nations. The first test at the Showground was held on 15 December 1934 between Australia and [[Great Britain national speedway team|Great Britain]] with Australia winning 35-19 in front of 50,000 paying fans. In March 1933, The Royale hosted the unofficial [[Speedway World Championship]], won by [[England]]'s [[Harry Whitfield]] from Australian's [[Billy Lamont (speedway rider)|Billy Lamont]] and future World Champion [[Bluey Wilkinson]]. During the 1960s and 1970s the Showground was Australia's best known and best attended speedway regularly drawing crowds on a Saturday night in excess of 10,000 and often over 30,000 making speedway one of the best attended spectator sports during the Australian summer. The speedway's promotor, John Sherwood (Empire Speedways who also promoted the [[Brisbane Exhibition Ground]]), was always looking for ways other than the racing itself to keep the crowds coming in. One of the more popular was the addition of [[Kings Cross, New South Wales|Kings Cross]] [[stripper]]s as trophy girls. From 1947 until 1974 the Speedway hosted the annual [[Australian Speedcar Grand Prix]], following which the race moved to the [[Liverpool Speedway]] in western Sydney before returning to the Showground in 1990. NSW drivers Ray Revell and Andy McGavin won a record 5 Speedcar Grand Prix's at the Showground while [[Bob Tattersall|Bob "Two Gun" Tattersall]] of the [[United States]] won the race four times in 1960, 1962, 1966 and 1969. One of the more unusual things at the speedway happened on 28 December 1975 when the so-called "Speedway Streaker" made his only appearance. Unlike the usual [[Streaking|streakers]] at sporting events who jump the fence and run around on the field until caught by either [[Police]] or [[Security]], this streaker rode out of the pits on a Solo motorbike completely naked other than a [[Motorcycle helmet|full faced helmet]] (to protect the guilty) and riding shoes. He did a quick lap of the track before laying the bike down on the infield. He was last seen jumping over the fence being chased by laughing policemen. Years later the streaker was revealed to be local solo rider Reg McCarthy. The Speedway ran continuous Saturday night meetings until the close of the 1980/81 season with Sydney fans spoiled for choice with the [[Parramatta City Raceway]] running on Friday nights and the Showground as well as [[Liverpool Speedway]] both running on Saturday nights. Like other suburban based speedways around Australia such as [[Rowley Park Speedway|Rowley Park]] in [[Adelaide]], the local residents around the showground began to complain not only about the noise but also the cars parking on the streets as the showground had very little in the way of designated car parks. With some residents having powerful friends on the [[City of Sydney]] council who made increasing restrictions on noise and parking and demanded that meetings be finished no later than 10:30pm (meetings traditionally finished around 11:30pm). This, combined with the advent of [[World Series Cricket]] in 1977 attracting a lot of the spectators, forced the speedway to close for regular meetings after 1981. What was hard to take for the promoter of the Showground, [[Brisbane]] based speedcar driver Ron Wanless, was that noise tests were conducted which proved that speedway meetings were actually quieter than sporting events at the neighbouring [[Sydney Cricket Ground]], the Royal Easter Show and open air music concerts held at either venue. Traffic was also reportedly less of a problem on speedway nights than for the Easter Show or when sports such as [[rugby league]] or [[cricket]] used the SCG. The showground enjoyed a brief revival in 1988 as a [[Australian Bicentenary|Bicentennial]] Solo Test Match was held between [[Australia national speedway team|Australia]] and [[Great Britain national speedway team|Great Britain]] attracting around 15,000 spectators. Unfortunately for the local fans, Great Britain defeated Australia on the night. The last ever Solo Test Match to take place at the Showground was held on 1 January 1994 with Australia taking on [[England national speedway team|England]]. Like the first ever Test at the Showground in 1934, Australia dominated and won 68 points to 40 in front of a crowd of just over 17,000. After 13 races held at the Liverpool Speedway, the Australian Speedcar Grand Prix returned to its traditional home as the Speedways only annual car racing event from 1990 until 1993 when the event was moved from the Speedway due to the same complaints that closed the Showground as a speedway in 1980, but returned for one last time in 1996 as the Showground was to be closed and turned into [[Fox Studios Australia]]. The 46th Australian Speedcar Grand Prix was held on 20 April. The race was won by the only competitor who had previously raced at the speedway, Australian speedway legend and 10 times [[Australian Sprintcar Championship|Australian Sprintcar Champion]] Garry Rush from western Sydney. It was his second win in the Grand Prix as he had won the 1977 event held on the asphalt at the [[Liverpool Speedway]]. One week later on Saturday 27 April 1996, approximately 25,000 fans saw Garry Rush win the last ever race held at the world-famous Sydney Showground Speedway when he took out the World Derby for Speedcars in a fitting end to the Showgrounds life as a speedway. Rush's wins in the last two main events at the Showground were for the same team with whom he had raced for at the venue some 30 years previously. Visiting American driver [[Jay Drake]] set the Showground lap record at the 20 April Grand Prix meeting when he ran the 509 metre oval in 16.876 seconds. When asked what he thought of the famous track, Drake described it as "Awfully narrow". ==Present day== The old Sydney Showgrounds and the Showground Speedway is now owned by and is part of [[Fox Studios Australia]] and although it now has a paved surface the track, and its narrow width, is still clearly visible. ==Lap records== *[[Midget car racing|Speedcars]]: 16.876 - {{Flagicon|USA}} [[Jay Drake]], 1996 *[[Sprint car racing|Sprintcars]]: 16.90 - {{Flagicon|USA}} Jimmy Sills, 1980/81 *[[Motorcycle Speedway|Solo]]: 18.80 - {{Flagicon|AUS}} Bill Landels (flying start) *Solo: 19.80 - {{Flagicon|AUS}} [[Jim Airey]] (clutch start) *[[Sidecar speedway|Sidecars]]: 20.20 - {{Flagicon|AUS}} Doug Tyerman (clutch start) *Sedans: 20.80 - {{Flagicon|AUS}} Ray Solway ==Fatalities== The Sydney Showground Speedway, like other speedways of the era, saw its share of competitor fatalities. In total there were 28 deaths at the speedway between 1926 and 1973. In December 2000, a plaque was unveiled at the Fox studios site of the former Speedway by longtime track announcer Jim Shepherd. The plaque overlooks the former start line alongside the Suttor Stand (built in 1909) which is now a cafe restaurant. The 28 who lost their lives at the Speedway Royale arehttp://bazilbrush.tripod.com/SPEEDWAYindex-7.html {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *Stanley Tyler - [[Motorcycle Speedway|Solo]] (13 November 1926) [[:Category:2008 in Kendo|2008]] ([[Zen Nihon Kendo Renmei Jodo|ZNKR Jōdō]]) |coach = '''Floorball''':
[[Petteri Bergman]] (men)
[[Kati Suomela]] (women)
'''Kendo''':
[[Kari Jääskeläinen]]
'''ZNKR Jōdō''':
[[Jarkko Lakkisto]] }} '''Tapanilan Erä''' is a [[Finland|Finnish]] [[sports club]] that was founded in 1933, with various teams in different disciplines. It is one of Finland's largest sporting clubs. ==Disciplines== ===Martial Arts=== *[[Boxing]] *[[Judo]] *[[Jujitsu]] *[[Karate]] *[[Kendo]] *[[Ki-Aikido]] *[[Zen Nihon Kendo Renmei Jodo|ZNKR Jōdō]] ===Other=== *[[Archery]] *[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]] *[[Badminton]] *[[Ballet]] *[[Bowling]] *[[Fencing]] *[[Floorball]] *[[Rhythmic Gymnastics]] *[[Tennis]] *[[Volleyball]] ==Floorball== The club's department of [[floorball]] was founded in [[:Category:1990 in Floorball|1990]]. In terms of licensed players, Erä's department of floorball is the fifthhttp://www.salibandy.net/liitto/ajankohtaista.asp?kieli=246&id=1207&alue=1{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} - Finnish Floorball Federation largest floorball club in Finland with 628 licensed players. Both the men's and women's teams play in the Finland's top floorball league, [[Salibandyliiga]]. The club also has 9 junior teams (5 boys, 4 girls). ===Team Achievements=== ====Men's==== *[[Suomen Cup (floorball)|2007 Finnish Cup]] Champions ====Women's==== *1996 [[Naisten Salibandyliiga]] Champions *1997 [[Naisten Salibandyliiga]] Champions * 1999 [[EuroFloorball Cup]] Champions * 2000 [[Naisten Salibandyliiga]] Champions * 2007 [[Naisten Salibandyliiga]] Champions ====Juniors==== *2004 [[Czech Open (floorball)|Czech Open]] Junior Division Champions ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.tapanila.com/ Club Homepage] * [http://www.tapanilanera.fi/ Floorball Homepage] {{Finnish Floorball League}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tapanilan Era}} [[Category:Sports teams in Finland]] [[Category:Finnish floorball teams]] [[Category:Sports clubs in Helsinki]] {{Finland-sport-stub}} {{Floorball-stub}}

Lyon]] | studio =[[Jack Broder Productions]] | distributor = Realart Pictures | released = August 1951 | runtime = 65 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Basketball Fix''''' is a 1951 American [[Film Noir]] [[sports film|sports]] [[drama film]] directed by [[Felix E. Feist]] and starring [[John Ireland (actor)|John Ireland]], [[Marshall Thompson]] and [[Vanessa Brown]]. The film is also known by the [[alternative title]] '''''The Big Decision''''' in the [[United Kingdom]]. A [[sports journalist]] tries to prevent a promising [[college athlete]] from becoming involved with a betting ring, but is unable to stop him [[Point shaving|shaving points]] off [[basketball]] games for them. == Cast == *[[John Ireland (actor)|John Ireland]] as Pete Ferreday *[[Marshall Thompson]] as Johnny Long *[[Vanessa Brown]] as Pat Judd *[[William Bishop (actor)|William Bishop]] as Mike Taft *[[Hazel Brooks]] as Lily Courtney *[[Johnny Sands]] as Jed Black *[[Robert Hyatt (actor)|Robert Hyatt]] as Mickey Long *[[Walter Sande]] as Nat Becker *[[Ted Pierson]] as Police Lt. {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Use British English|date=January 2015}} {{ infobox stadium | name = Wavertree Sports Park | nickname = | image = Wavertree, Liverpool, sports centre - geograph.org.uk - 1746640.jpg | image_size = 250px | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[Wavertree]], [[Liverpool]], [[Merseyside]] | coordinates = {{coord|53.397|-2.925|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Liverpool City Council]] | operator = Lifestyles | surface = | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = }}
'''Wavertree Sports Park''' is a large sporting, exercise and leisure complex located in the [[Wavertree]] area of [[Liverpool]], [[England]]. The sports park is home to the Liverpool Aquatics Centre, Liverpool Tennis Centre and Wavertree Athletics Centre alongside numerous other health and fitness related facilities.
==Liverpool Tennis Centre== Liverpool Tennis Centre has six indoor acrylic tennis courts and six outdoor macadam tennis courts, four of which are floodlit. The venue was built with funding from the Lawn Tennis Association, Sport England and Liverpool City Council. It has hosted major tennis competitions, including the Liverpool International Tennis Tournament in 2003 and the Nike Junior International in 2013 and 2014. Until recently, the Centre was closed to the public during the day but is now open from 9.00am every day for coaching and pay-and-play customers.
== Liverpool Aquatics Centre == The Liverpool Aquatic Centre is a £17million development. It opened on 15 March 2008. The development has two swimming pools, one Olympic standard 8-lane 50 metre pool and a smaller four lane 20m pool.<ref>[http://www.colsc.net/htm/lac.htm http://www.colsc.net/htm/lac.htm]</ref> It cost £2.1million to maintain in 2008.<ref name=lac-cost>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpooldailypost.co.uk/liverpool-news/regional-news/2009/01/31/liverpool-s-olympic-swimming-pool-cost-taxpayers-1-5m-64375-22822908/|title= Liverpool's Olympic swimming pool cost taxpayers £1.5m|last=Bartlett|first=David|date=31 January 2009|publisher=Liverpool Daily Post|accessdate=23 January 2010}}</ref> To fund the build, £13m was borrowed by Liverpool City Council. The final bill will be £31m, once the debt is repaid in 2008, at a cost of £1.3m a year.<ref name=lac-cost />
==Wavertree Athletics Centre== [[File:Athletics track, Wavertree Playground - geograph.org.uk - 39239.jpg|thumb|left|Exterior athletics track]] The Wavertree Athletics Centre was a training facility for the 2012 Summer Olympics.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/olympics/london_2012/7275361.stm|title= Olympic training venues - North West|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 January 2010 | date=2008-03-03}}</ref> The capacity of the athletics stadium is 480. There is an outdoor 8 lane 400 metres synthetic running track and an interior 4-lane 60 metre track. It is home to Liverpool Harriers and Athletic Club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolharriers.co.uk|title=Liverpool Harriers|accessdate=23 January 2010}}</ref> The stadium hosted the first ever baseball World Cup game in 1938.
==References== <references/>
